This 3D corvette emblem is the first one of a series for corvette brand lovers to be print in 3D and framed

Have fun

title: Horizon Hobby Super Cub Brushless Motor Adapter

description.text:
This is another alternative for substituting the Horizon Hobby's brushed motor to the brushless option on the Super Cub. It is one-piece (no assembly required). Can be printed without supports (single extruder), even though some bridging has to be done towards the top of the print. However, with .125" thickness there's plenty of strength even if some stringiness occurs at lower bridging layers.

The new adapter now has over 2 hours flying time on it with no issues or problems. The original plane was slightly nose heavy and the new brushless motor helps offset the CG a bit more aft. This may not be the case for every HH Super Cub, but it doesn't hurt to check the CG before flying anyway.

comments.text: Tommy2toes - it flies a little faster, but quite a bit more efficiently. Twice as long as the factory motor. Not sure about doing tricks though. Mine only has the rudder and elevator for controls. No ailerons. It's a good park flier though. Cheers!
comments.author: Classicaviator

comments.text: does it fly better or longer can it do tricks now? i happen to have both the cub and extra motor if it helps the plane at all. kool adaptor thanks for sharing!
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: no prob thanks.

what size motor ?

Happy Holidays......Oh and awesome of you to put this here !
comments.author: Classicaviator

comments.text: Happy Thanksgiving to you too, drumsz! And, no problem on posting stuff here. I love sharing. It's the way it should always be! :-)
comments.author: drumsz

comments.text: I think it was 20 kv, but can't remember for sure. Next time I am going through my R/C stuff in the garage, I will take a look. Sorry for a late response.
comments.author: drumsz

comments.text: never mind, I see that the brushed motor mount is sloped too. I wonder why they did this. Maybe the offset of the motor to one side which I don't understand either.
comments.author: Rangler6475

comments.text: Most small RC planes have their motors turned to the side and slightly down. The turn to the side is to help offset P-factor and torque generated by the motor and the prop. The downward sloping is to help maintain somewhat level flight in high wing airplane due to drag forces from the wing causing the plane to pitch up on power up. Hope this helps :-)
comments.author: Rangler6475

comments.text: I really appreciate the solidworks part file, but why is the thing sloped?

description.text: Doorway molding for 1:12 scale doll houses.

The included openscad source lets you customize the length and width of the piece.  Although an stl is provided, you probably don't want to print that unless you're making a Greenleaf McKinley doll house.  The finished product just slips right over the raw doorway opening and holds in place quite well - no tools required.  
Note that the vertical and horizontal trims are different.  The horizontal has two 45 degree cuts, the vertical only one.  If you want to print a horizontal molding (ie. the overhead piece), set isHorizontal to 1.  For vertical pieces (with only one 45 degree cut), set isHorizontal to 0.

title: FPV Ground Station Power Charging Box with Voltage and Temperature

description.text:
MESSAGE ME IMAGES OF YOUR PRINTS, I'LL ADD THEM TO THE PAGE!

This Power Box has holes for USB Female jacks, Standard 5.5mm Power Jacks, XT60 Connectors and 3S JST-XH Balance connectors. Sections for a cheap EBay Voltage and Temperature sensor are included. Finally, a little section to hold the little things in the center.

Those big holes are for circular switches, easily found on EBay. They could be used to trigger some ground station gadgets (e.g. Monitor, Rx, DVR, etc.) I've also left space for a small label below each switch.

Measurements: 150mm x 150mm x 70mm X,Z,Y

My first little design for an upcoming project of mine, feel free to use it yourself! Originally designed for a 43x31 flight case.

  • Happy Flying -
    www.youtube.com/32bitbrad

1) Print it out, a large print area may be needed. (150mm x 150mm x 70mm Minimum X,Z,Y)

2) Insert your components and solder everything together.

3) The top plate should slot nicely into the casing, use a bit of glue to secure it.

4) Happy Flying!

Nixius is a DIY nixie tube clock.

What can it do? Display time and temperature. Turns off and on automatically at some preset time so you don't have to turn it off when you go to sleep. Simple really.

This here is just the case for it. All you need is print it. You need the main case, a back cover and three buttons. I've included an stl version that includes mouse ears for better printing experience - so the thing doesn't unstick during printing.

This is a model of a hyperbolic paraboloid x^2-y^2=2z, labeled with its equation. There is a second .stl file showing the surface without the equation. There is a third .stl file with the surface with equation in arial font.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). For more information see http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/21/quadratic-surfaces-hyperbolic-paraboloid/.

We printed this model using the FormLabs Form1+ printer.

We printed in black, each layer 0.1mm. The model printed upright, rather than lying on its side as shown in the .stl file.

The print was an excellent quality, with only a few supports and a very smooth surface. However, we had some trouble with the number 2 on the equation.

A simple vase using a twisted octagonal prism :)

To print vase shapes properly, remember to set 0% infill, 0 top filled layers, and define the thickness of the walls and bottom in your software under the relevant settings (usually 'bottom solid layers' and 'perimeters')!

To print vase shapes properly:

Set 0% infill, 0 top filled layers, and define the thickness of the walls and bottom in your software under the relevant settings (usually 'bottom solid layers' and 'perimeters')! If you actually want to use this as a functional vase you'll need more outer and bottom layers- mine slowly drips water but only had 5 perimeter and bottom layers.

NOTE this is a long print depending on your printer! It took over 19 hours using 0.1mm layer thickness for a 0.8 scale model.

For PLA Filament knob, I created a knob without the tabs and used a stopper instead works just as good.

title: Virtual Reality Goggles for Android Smartphone

description.text: After looking around the MTBS3D Forums I stumbled across a design of a 3D printable mask to allow you to use your Android phone as a VR 3D HMD. (Original can be found here: http://www.durovis.com/index.html). I liked the idea behind this but after printing the actual device there was a few bits that I didn't get on with so decided to start playing with Google sketchup to come up with my own version. I printed this out on a RepRap so should print out fine on any 3d printer. You can then use the native Android Demos from the OpenDive website. Or you canuse the Vireio Perception drivers along with FreePIE and Splashtop to stream PC games to your phone in 3D with headtracking (This is not as good as a proper HMD such as the Oculus Rift but it does work!!) This was designed to be used with my Samsung Galaxy S4 phone. But it should work with any Android Smartphone of a similar size.

This is fairly simple to build.  
Print out the main body, The lens holder and 2 of the Head Clips.  
You will need 2x 25mm Lenses (Something like the ones you get out of toy binoculars). I actually got mine out of a telescope eyepiece. You can also purchase a pair of lenses from the opendive website. You may need to sand the lens holes down slightly to get a tight fit for your lenses.  
I have included the google sketchup files so if you need to modify the size of the holes for the lenses you can. You can also change the IPD to match your own so 3D viewing will be better.  
Once you have printed the part, just put them all together and use 2 elastic bands to hold your phone.  
Use 2 M3x20mm nuts and bolts to hold the lens holder in place once you have adjusted the focus to match your lenses. Then attach and elastic fabric band to use as a head strap.  
I also used some 13mm Draft excluder to pad out the edges of the item so it doesn't damage your phone or your face!! :-)

description.text:
At work we had a project that required the use of a magnetic reed switch on a door that was to thin for the conventional hole mounting method. I devised this holder to allow you to mount the magnet on the face of the door and still have the switch closed when the door is closed.

This is for a switch sold as a RC36 available from many retailers for around $2-$3. The hole for the magnet is approximately 7/8"

I made three versions:

MH00- is the base magnet holder
MH-H05 has a horizontal offset of 1/2" from that of the MH00 holder
MH-V05 has a vertical offset of 1/2" from that of the MH00 holder

These files we designed in onshape

UPDATE- 8/12/2015
Here is the link to the Onshape source files:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/9648ac2696534c6b86b0440d/w/dd639c0a49fc4babbdf6dfb1/e/591230847bb34951aa33deef

Files are sized in millimeters

UPDATE- 8/12/2015

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/9648ac2696534c6b86b0440d/w/dd639c0a49fc4babbdf6dfb1/e/591230847bb34951aa33deef

I wasn't happy with the inside diameter of the other cable chains, so I edited an existing design and created this one :)

You can check out the video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGb_3tLH8zI

If you haven't already, make sure you subscribe to my YouTube Channel as I'm designing and experimenting with all things 3D Print related! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTifhHi3SSt_om6C3IAay6w

The original file was from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:71125/

title: Z-knob stop for MakerGear M2 dual

description.text:
This is a second attempt to create a useful locking mechanism for the MakerGear M2's Z-axis knob. The first version, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:873378, does not allow the M2 dual extruder carriage to move all the way to the left. This version stays clear of the extruder carriage in all positions while keeping the feature of releasing itself if the Z stage is homed while the lock is still in place. It has the additional feature that the lock handle can be placed upside-down on the cap and makes a convenient handle for hand-cranking the Z stage.

Updated July 22; knob now has a small overhang at the top, which helps stop the lever from twisting in the locked position, and also helps keep the level from slipping out when using it as a hand crank.

This knob works only with the low-profile Z-axis knob that comes with the dual extruder upgrade for the MakerGear M2. It comes in two pieces, a knob cap and a handle. Both print without issue, although the knob cap will need support.

The knob cap gets placed over the Z-axis knob, and can stay in place more or less permanently, as it does not interfere with any of the parts of the dual M2. The handle has a hole that fits over the pin on the knob cap. To lock the Z-stage, place the handle so that it points downward on the left side of the frame. The weight of the Z-stage will cause the handle to hit the side of the frame, preventing any further drop. If the Z-stage is lifted, either by homing the Z axis or homing all axes, the handle will be pulled off of the cap, automatically unlocking the Z stage. The handle can be placed on the knob cap upside-down to make a convenient handle for hand-cranking the Z stage when the motors are disengaged.

The designed is based of a google earth model.The body had to be modified as it was unstable, and the face has been modified since it was getting messed up when printing. Let me know how it works!

title: Golden Ratio Sand Castle Mold - Work in Progress

description.text:
This is my first attempt at a 3D model of any kind, inspired by the Thingiverse BuildACastle challenge. I'm not a "math person" by any means, but I've always been interested in the golden ratio; these models are an attempt to create a sand castle mold which creates little golden ratio sand castles!

First attempt was fairly awful, the cylinder shapes are accurate golden ratio numbers, but they aren't matched up right.

The second attempt (the wedges) I'm much happier with, but it's still not a perfect golden ratio.

description.text:
This is a protector which prevents the blades of a fan to be touched by small fingers, or by most of the accidentally sucked things.

It does not reduce the airflow, and does not create any additional noise.

This one is scaled for a 40 mm fan, but the concept can be rescaled for any other size.

The 4 M3 bolts are deeply inserted into the colums in order to not uselessly increase the weight with longer ones.

The SKETCHUP file is also attached.

this is a mount to make a futaba style trainer port plug for powering things such as FPV monitors and WIFI boosters. 2 prongs from a PCB rail will fit diagonally with a bit of straitening.

the 2 middles pins are + and - (google the pinout to verify) but the top middle pin in - and the bottom middle pin is switched + (when the controller is on)

best printed at 50mm/s and at arouns 0.1mm layer height

NOTE this is not polarity "dummy" proof. The notch on the outter of the rail part should be lined up with where the notch should go...
-just mark it and make sure you plug it in right.. the notch made the print alot more difficult to get a good clean finished product..

This is a water bottle holder compatible with bikes with the mounting PEMS, and with bikes without any mounting points.

This is a modification of the previous version:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:433177

This newer version has no sharp angles that tended to create weak places that would tend to break.

Try to print it low quality to get a high level of layer adhesion.

Print 3-5 shell layers.

If you have screw pems on your bike, Simply screw this holder onto them. The holes should line up well.

Otherwise, I got ahold of some 3M VHB tape and put it on the back of the part. I then wire ties it down shoving the wire ties through the channels in this part.

description.text:
This is a two-part functional mallet, emblazoned with "sudo" - the Linux command for "super user do" which informs the machine to do the next command with all the might and authority of a super-user.  
As with traditional mallets, the shaft and head are separate and are a wedging fit. This also allows the printing laminations to be arranged for maximum strength (it works fine with Diamond Age PLA). Inside the head are filler holes that allow you to weight the head with ironsand or lead shot etc.  
The logo may be changed for other words if you wish.  
Whosoever holds this hammer, if he be worthy, shall possess the power of sudo.
Also useful for muting ukuleles.

title: Arduino mega r3 box v4 - Lid

description.text:
I made a lid for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:279537 , to fit an Arduino Mega (or Uno) and an ethernet shield. It has a nice light 'snap' together feel, and is tight enough to hold together by itself with its contents. But, it's hold is not too tight, so you can still take it apart easily when needed. I am actually amazed at how well it holds the case together without screws. May make an update later to add a cut out for an 1602 LCD.

Assembly:
Start with the jack end, and slip the front edge (side with square hole) in first at a 45 degree angle. Watch those tabs, they will break if you get impatient.

-Update, I added more tabs and made them stronger and sharper. Seems to hold together by itself pretty good, it kind of just self snaps together. May add slots and hooks later for a better, more permanent, snap fastened hold. This design will hold its own weight (bottom+mega+ethernet shield+top) and stay together if held moderately gently. Use .stl file v4.

Credit to DCDesigns for the original box. http://www.thingiverse.com/Dcdesigns/about

Solidoodle4 .3mm resolution ABS
200/100 degrees
Takes about 1.5 hours or less to print at .3mm

Assembly:
Start with the jack end, and slip the front edge (side with square hole) in first at a 45 degree angle. Watch those tabs, they will break if you get impatient.

A double barreled nerf blowgun with a 24 dart capacity. Identical in function to the Plusblow 5, but uses the more common Nerf Elite / Streamline darts.

See the video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=frRRKE2z8Ak

1. Print 1 each of the .stl files. You may need to adjust the hole fit for your individual printer--a .stp file is provided for those that have a CAD system to edit the parts.

  2. Cut 4 pieces of 9/16" ID, 5/8" OD plastic tube to equal lengths. I got mine from McMaster #8628K57 . I used 30" to get the 24 dart capacity and to best use the 5 foot long segments of tube.

  3. File the top of the dart holder drum so it's smooth enough to superglue, then glue that surface to the bottom of the mouthpiece, lining up the holes as best you can.

  4. Drill out the center hole to 1/4" as needed, then put a 6" long 1/4-20 screw through the mouthpiece, dart holder drum, and the magazine holder drum. The smooth bottom surfaces of the dart holder drum and the magazine holder drum should be pressed against each other. The head of the screw should be on the mouthpiece side.

  5. Put a 1/4-20 nut loosely on the screw. Tighten it down so that the dart holder drum and magazine holder drum are gently pressed against each other.

  6. Put a dab of superglue just above the nut from step 6, then put another 1/4-20 nut on the screw. Tighten the nuts against each other, but not against the printed parts. At the end of this step, the magazine holder drum should be pressed against the rest of the assembly, but not so hard that it's difficult to turn.

  7. Insert the four 9/16" x 5/8" plastic tubes.

  8. Place the front magazine holder on the barrels/magazines at the front of the blowgun. Press everything together.

  9. Add a strip of rubber or other flexible material in the provided slot to create a dart-retaining flap. I hot-glued a couple strips of rubber in there, but you could achieve the same effect with cardboard or folded paper if need be.

  10. Put some orange tape on the tip of this to prevent anyone from getting butthurt about toy gun ID.

To load the magazines, push darts past the flaps into the thinwall PVC magazines. With this length, you should be able to fit 11 into each of the two magazine tubes. To load darts into the firing chambers/ barrels, just tilt back and rotate the mouthpiece/dart holder drum 90 degrees. To fire, just blow each of the two mouthpiece holes in front of the barrels.

Accuracy will suffer greatly compared to the Plusblow 5 unless elite suction darts are used, because regular elite darts don't fly straight.

title: Oak & Maple leaves for decorating pie crusts

description.text:
Decorate the rim of pies with pieces of crust cut from the same crust as the pie.

For the Maple leaf, started with the outline from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:121331
The original needed to be scaled to be smaller & then thickened, resulting in thin or no walls on my printer so I used the outline from it.

The maple leaf initially was a bit smaller than the oak leaf so: an additional stl maple leaf part file (25% larger) has been included, to more closely match the oak leaf.
After printing, I left the rim on the oak leaf for grip.

Press the cutter into the pie crust holding the rim and separate the core from the cutter. Moisten the back side of the leaf and point on the crust where it will be placed. Then press the two together around the rim or decorate the center of the pie. Could even cut cores from the center area of the pie crust for decoration.

description.text:
This is a bike wheel truing stand that was made with 3d printed parts, a harbor freight dial indicator gauge, and 1" (1/16" wall) steel tubing, which should cost about 1$/foot.

Parts total should come out to ~5$ or ~20$ counting the gauge.

For now you'll have to refer to the photo for assembly.

The welded parts are all 1" square tube with 1/16" wall. I'm happy to share the solidworks files if people want to make a no-weld version that uses something like 80/20 or openbeam.

The vertical tubes measure roughly 15" tall. Note that the left tube is 14" inches with a second tube welded to the top to make 15". A standard road bike wheel (700c) measures 700mm in diameter with tire so as long as the vertical tubes are >350mm you'll be fine. The vertical tubes are spaced 5.5" apart (inside wall to inside wall), this distance was to accommodate standard road bike rear hubs, which are ~5.25 (130mm) wide. There is enough extra length in "side_part" that you don't have to be too accurate.

Assembly should be done in the following order. (see numbered photo)
1) Weld metal parts
2) Insert top_part into the longest tube
3) Drill a >5mm hole in the center the left top tube as pictured (see where the wing nut sticks out)
4) Fasten a M5 bolt with the head captive on the interior of side_part and the wingnut on the exterior. This allows manual locking of the side_part.
5) Place a wheel in the true stand.
6) With wheel in place measure out and center punch the location for the gauge bracket. Then drill 3/32" holes (or the proper metric size ~2.6-2.7mm if you've got it) and tap with M3-0.5 threads. Finally screw the bracket in place.
7) If using the harbor freight gauge then it should attach with an M6x16mm bolt and a wingnut.

If any of this doesn't make sense please leave a comment. If anyone out there wants to make one and needs an assembly drawing I'll take the time to make one. :)

title: DIY Homemade Flashlight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Children 7+ can learn how to create circuits using things found at home! You can make a simple circuit inside the provided frames to make a working flashlight! Before you start, make sure to have an adult helping because circuits can be dangerous! After following the instructions, you should have a working flashlight! If it works and doesn't fall apart, you got it!

After many hours of designing on Tinkercad, I finished creating the body of the flashlight. Then after many MORE hours, I finished the top part. Even though it took SO LONG, I am proud of what I have created!

To create this, I had to use SO MANY hole functions to smooth out the parts and to hollow out parts.

Things You'll Need

-The printed parts
-2 M4x8mm screws (I had extra from building my 3D printer)
-1 small paperclip
-1 small light bulb (I found one from an old flashlight, but an LED from Christmas lights will do)
-1 spring (from a pen)
-2 AA batteries
-tape
-2 wires (each 4 inches) (I cut some from old Christmas lights)
-some tin/aluminum foil
-super glue 

                                                 Instructions

CHECK ABOVE FOR PICTURES OF EACH STEP

THROUGHOUT THE ASSEMBLY, MAKE SURE TO TEST THE CIRCUIT ALONG THE WAY

  1. Tape the two batteries together, one on top of another, with the opposite poles touching.
  2. Super glue the spring on to the center of the bottom cap.
  3. Thread a screw through an end of the paperclip.
  4. Put an end of the wire through the bottom hole on the side of the body and thread it almost all the way through. Stop when just a few centimeters are sticking out.
  5. Push the screw into the hole and screw it in with the wire sticking out. This will hold the wire in place. Don't screw it too tight, or else you won't be able to move the screw!
  6. With the other screw and wire, do the same to the top hole on the side of the body.
  7. Tape the other end of the wire to the side of the light bulb. Tape it good!
  8. Put the light bulb through the top cap so only the bulb part is showing and the wires are hidden.
  9. Super glue the cap onto the body.
  10. With the bottom wire's end (the one we haven't done anything with yet) wrap it around the spring.
  11. Push the bottom lid up against the body to close it.
  12. Wrap the inside of the light reflector with the foil. Secure it with tape around the edges of the reflector.
  13. Super glue the reflector onto the top of the top cap.
  14. To turn it on, touch the paperclip to the other screw. To turn it off, remove the paperclip from the screw.

title: MPCNC custom brushless spindle IE version  - Iteration 1

description.text:
mpcnc brushless spindle - small edition;

Bigger version with 5050 Brushless motor coming soon...

Did you know the 608ZZ bearings fit well into the 25mm ALU Conduit ?
Well...let's make a custom spindle...
https://youtu.be/ryJoEq1HYZQ

Basically you need 25mm OD conduit with 22mm inner diameter.
ALU conduit: 70-80mm.

You need to slowly squeeze the bearings into the conduit.
part list:
3x 608ZZ bearing.
ER11 Collet with 100mm length.
1xGT2 155T belt
1x16T GT2 pulley
1x36T GT2 pulley
1x2212 brushless motor
1x30A ESC
Arduino (nano for example) for spindle speed control (PWM)

Instructions and part list coming soon.

comments.text: Nice work.
comments.author: Allted

comments.text:
Hi Alted,
No, unfortunately i just fried my first ESC somehow with the Arduino speed control thing :-).
The ALU is not the best choice i think for bigger machine. Actually i'm about to replacing all the the ALU to steel, because the ALU is simple too soft against the bearings...
Another thing here: the whole machine is a little bit "flexible" because of the ALU pipes (in "Z" direction) and yes there is a small "ditch" path on the PIPE because of the bearings.
On the other hand the ALU works well and i think the ALU is perfect for cutting "soft" materials or to build machine up to 25x25" or so.

author: Ron80

description.text:
Character Tsubaki from Soul Eater. She has the ability to transform into multiple weapons, including a kusarigama (chain scythe).

Modio/Tinkerplay compatible at 100% size.

This is a large 4" diagonal to diagonal 7 segment display. It uses 20 5mm LED's and the colours are completely your choice. In my version, i built it with 20 bi-coloured (Red and Green) LED's which had a diffused lens.

This is great to use on walls and makes an awesome clock, temperature monitor or maybe use it to display the number of unread emails in your inbox!

There are 6 files that make up this display however some parts need to be printed twice.

Print the 7_Segment_Display_Frame, 7_Segment_Dot and 7_Segment_G stl files just ONCE. The rest of the parts need to be printed TWICE each. You will notice that the file name corresponds to the correct layout of a generic 7 segment display

For the electronics, I've provided an Instructable which you can view here: http://www.instructables.com/id/4-Seven-Segment-Display/

title: Lee Load Master shell slider adapter .40 S&W;

description.text: This adapter is used to level the top of the slide to a .40 S&W case. This reduces the number of shell tipping when the case tube is full of brass.

I did the following:

PLA
50% in fill
raft (You may not need this)
support: 1 mm (in simplify3d) I then hand removed the supports from the "40 s&w" text in simplify3d.

It works just fine if you end up snapping off the thin leg on the side. I had to ramp the front of my slide adapter with a modeling knife and sandpaper. This allows some wiggle room and allows the next case to slide up if needed.

comments.text: Nice design - I had to scale it up about 7% in width, otherwise it would not fit over the LEE part.

This thing is a replacement backplate for the common HID contactless/proximity card readers (iClass, multiClass, youfailedyourClass, etc). I needed it because I purchased a pivClass reader on eBay that didn't come with a backplate.

UPDATE

I recently realized that this backplate apparently only works for the readers that have an integrated keypad. They look like this:

The readers without a keypad apparently have a deeper screw hole. Modification of the OpenSCAD source should be relatively easy. I may update it myself later if I find the need.

title: Car Stereo DIN/ISO Slot Cover for SD-Cards

description.text: Moved here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/car-stereo-din-iso-slot-cover-for-sd-cards I do not support companies forcing lawsuits based on trivial patents against other 3D printer companies. DIN slots (DIN 75490/ISO 7736) for car stereos come in two sizes: single and double height. If a single height device is mounted to a double height slot, the remaining space is usually covered with a useless plastic cover. I mainly use SD cards, and sometimes USB sticks for sound storage. Disadvantage of miniaturization: they tend to get lost. That's why I wanted to use that space below the car stereo for keeping my media safe.

Two models provided: one for heated beds without additional stuff, one with extra parts to reduce warp. Cut away after print. The second one must be flipped upside down. Both can be printed with exterior support only. Some support has been added to avoid support everwhere mode, the slots bridged well without. Note: printing time up to 10h, depending on your settings. Depeding on warp the outer USB slots may need some work to fit. The front of the part on the pictures has been sanded dry and wet, which gives it a really smooth finish. I don't use all USB slots, so I added a simple clip to plug into one USB slot which can hold a standard hexagonal pencil.

description.text: Lincoln Memorial by Kiana designed with Tinkercad
Model of the Lincoln Memorial by Kiana using Tinkercad. 10% fill, 2 shells, .3 layer height, no supports

comments.text: I printed this with supports just because I was afraid that the top would sag if I didn't. It's a pain to remove all of the support material, but not too bad with some patience. The big thing I have found, and should have seen before I printed, is that none of the columns go all the way to the bottom platform. So, they printed on support material which is very flimsy. I dislodged several while cleaning out the support material. It's nothing that some superglue can't fix, but this should be fixed in the model itself. Also, the bottom platform has some space inside it that is weird. It's difficult to explain, but if you look at it in 3d view, you can see it. The problem is that the bottom platform is only attached to the second platform on 1 side, which makes it a little flimsy. Again, nothing that some superglue can't fix, but it should be an easy fix on the model itself.

title: Very early prototype for Red Pop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was the original model that went on to inspire the design of Red Pop, the big red button for your iPhone camera - http://www.red-pop.com which we're bringing to market via Kickstarter: http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/786496402/red-pop Using Makerbot I was able to quickly create a kind of physical sketch of the idea; something to hold in our hands so we could get a sense of how it feels, what size it needed to be etc. Plus it was something to use as we developed the idea further. Yes the idea of rapid prototyping has been around for ages but for me, as well as having the ability to make finished objects, Makerbot and machines like them allow me to make real the things that had previously existed as pencil on paper. Encouraged by Bre from Makerbot I've put this original model up here because I wanted to share how having the ability to literally hold the beginnings of an idea in your hands can then inspire you to take things further.

author: brendandawes

description.text:
My wife saw something like this at the craft store and thought it was cute, but said she wasn't going to pay 15 dollars for it. I told her that i thought i could make one. I don't know if you would call this a "mash-up" or a "derivative" but had fun making it. I made the pink one for my daughter, but it printed wierd for some reason... it still worked though. the high heel is:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31218 The pieces of the tape dispenser are from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16169
I did modify the size of the wheel to fit the tape roll better.

• Print
    • .4 layer height
    • 3 shells
    • 25% infill
    • Use support. i tried to slice it into 2 halves, but it just didn't work right
    • Print the tape wheel horizontally
  • Remove support, and sand pieces
  • Insert wheel into roll of tape
  • Install wheel into shoe. i had to use a little force to get the roll to pop in, but if it breaks just make another wheel.
    • This thing is more for fun, than for everyday use. It is light, and tips over when you get the tape. My fingers are too big to use the tape cutter without flipping the whole thing over, but my daughter loves it, and doesn't seem to have any trouble using it. This was fun. thanks to TheNewHobbyist for his tape dispenser and MakerBot for the high heel.

comments.text: Haha, just saw the tape dispenser you're talking about at the store tonight. Glad you could find a use for my tape dispenser!

author: arwyn

title: Robo 3D x-axis wiring guide w/screw holes

description.text:
I loved the original design but the cable kept interfering with the filament.

So I modified the file and removed the feet attachment for the slit and added a extension so you can use the screw holes already in the R1 production version (not sure if kickstarter version has those) Also pushes the loop more to the front of the printer (or the back if you prefer - just turn 180 degrees)

I'm a total novice in 3D modeling so it might not be perfect but I know it will fit. (it fit on mine)

Even though the Chain link available looks really cool, I'm not comfortable removing all the wires and re-attaching. I think this is really simple and easy solution to remove/replace.

This is a Remix of the EthanNewhouse version
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:929486

Make sure you print the top guide modification on it's side so you don't need any support material.

Remove the zip tie and then remove the screws on the little black piece that it was attached to.

You then use the same screws to screw on the modification - don't need to screw on tight - will bend a little but it can take it.

after that, works the same as the EthanNewhouse version.

Specs:
PLA
HatchBox Dark Blue
Temp 215C
Bed 55C
Infill 20% Hexagon
.2mm layer height

comments.text: I dig the modification.  This is exactly what I love about design.  You can take an existing design and make it optimized for your own use, or take the concept and make something new.  Great job and keep at it.
comments.author: EthanNewhouse

comments.text: Thanks @EthanNewhouse - Your original design was great
comments.author: EthanNewhouse

This is a night light designed for LED lighting - I don't recommend using a candle. The sides clip together and just rest on a base with a cover resting on top. The base has a deep cavity to accommodate any LED arrangement and there is an open channel for wiring to the outside, for a bigger battery or mains supply. Without the cover and base, it can be used as a decorative surround for a narrow vase.

I have added a base variant. It is the same size but has ridges all around for decorative purposes only. The channel was printed without support.
I have added two side variants. The holes and tabs are in the same place so the sides could be mixed instead of having each side the same.

Print two copies of each side panel and then clip them together with the tabs in the corresponding holes. The base and cover are not clipped in or stuck, they are intended to be easily removable. It is possible to print the sides and cover of this design absolutely smooth without any evidence of filament build-up. Because the sides are symmetrical, they can be fitted with print bed outwards and the filament lines facing inwards. Since the cover is printed upside down by virtue of the widest pad sitting on the print bed, when this is assembled it also display an absolutely surface.

Minecraft papercraft, but setup for a lasercutter. I use a sturdy cardstock that's coated white on one side.

In the illustrator files, I've got two different colors for the lines in the vectors - one for the actual Cuts and another or the 'etch' lines. The etch lines should be done done at a very very light setting so it doesn't cut all the way through. It'll put creases in the areas that should be folded to make that part easy.

The svg files are exported out of illustrator, and I have no idea how well those will work in whatever program you have for reading them, so be forewarned that you may need to go in and make adjustments.

This is an orthodox cross I made for putting on a necklace rope. I will have to redesign this because the details do not come out right on my slicer unless scaled up really high.

A castle topper to show off your mathematical prowess while molding the sands!

Based off of a 3D projection of the equation Z = sin(​sqrt(​x^​2+​y^​2))/​sqrt(​x^​2+​y^​2), simply pack the mold with wet sand and add it to your castle for an awesome accent!

When I saw this challenge I knew I wanted to create an interactive and interesting way to view mathematics in the 3rd dimension, having it look really awesome is just a plus!

To make this model I used blender 3D modeling software, subdivided a plane into ~65k vertices and set each vertex to where it would be when plugged into the formula. From there all I did was create the mold around the function.

Unfortunately where I live I didn't have access to any sand to mold so I used brown sugar instead.

Edit: Added a solid version for those who just want a neat model of the function.

Edit (7/31/15): Made and uploaded a much cleaner and useful version, it prints without support and allows a cleaner sand mold, plus this one actually works in slic3r.

Edit(7/14/15): Made a version with the function on the side.

No supports needed! Just print pack and play!

The base model is 10cm x 10cm x 4cm, use that to scale it to any size you want

author: Bophoto

description.text:
UPDATE: I've been unable to find a reliable way to protect the plastic with this design. If you're using PLA, keep reading; people have had good results. If you're printing with ABS however, I recommend using this updated design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11025 The Coin-Op Bottle Opener ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1842 ) is awesome on so many levels. No wonder it's often the first thing that gets printed on a new machine. It doesn't take long to see its weakness though: it's HUGE. This design keeps the same (strong, satisfying) jaw geometry, but puts it in a package that isn't a burden on your pants pocket. Also, because it's much smaller, it takes FAR less time to print. One drawback is that you need to man-handle a paper clip to keep the plastic from getting chewed up. On the plus side you get to call yourself "crafty." Also I removed most of the handle, so you may have to adjust your normal hand position. I find this opener works best with my thumb on top, index finger underneath. (I've left this as a "work in progress" for the time being. It has done well in my testing, but please let me know if something doesn't work for you) History:
  • Part gets submitted using a modified bottle cap as the protector. looks awesome (it's still the title thumbnail)
  • Thing gets featured.
  • Turns out the bottle cap protector doesn't work all that well. Embarrassing update posted. (good thing it's a "work in progress")
  • Furious design session yeilds improved paper clip design. (thanks go out to thingiverse users waaronw and jprodgers for their contributions to that process)
  • Made the part ~1mm wider (to help the fill around the hole) and added a little recess for the paperclip on the back side.

Getting the Paper clip into the opener is pretty straight forward (see picture):
  • Straighten the paperclip and bend it into a U.
  • Slide the clip through the slots in the part until the U is flush with the back of the opener.
  • Bend the free ends so that they are flush with the front of the jaw.
  • Trim the ends so there is just enough wire left for the next step.
  • Bend the wires back forming 2 new U's. The points should be lodged into the plastic at the back of the jaw. This will keep everything nice and snug.

title: Z-Axis microadjustable endstop holder for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
This is a mechanism I designed for holding for the Z-axis endstop, such that the endstop is mounted to a movable lift that can be tweaked up and down relative to the clamp by fractions of a millimeter with the turn of a screw. Three hex standoffs are attached to the top piece but allowed to travel freely through guide holes in the bottom piece to keep the deck level as you turn the set screw. A spring provides upward tension to keep everything stiff. Relative to the clamp, the endstop is mounted at an angle, which gets the adjustment screw out from under the X-end bracket so that it can be easily turned from above. To assemble it, you will need:
  • The two printed parts.
  • A M3x20mm screw and nut
  • Three hexagonal standoffs, approx 20mm long and 6mm in diameter, along with three mating screws (I use 4-40, 3/16").
  • A spring, such as is used by many people for mounting their heated bed.
  • Oh, and an endstop and the screws to attach it (I use M2x16 screws and nuts).
    • Note: When you assemble it, make sure to get a lot of compression on the spring. This device is intended for just that last +/- 2mm adjustment, so you don't need much coil left in the spring. The model is parametric, so you can adjust the hole dimensions and some of the other features to suit you. Please share your ideas for improvements if you build it. Some day, I may reach a state of reprap nirvana where my Z axis never shifts by a few tenths of a mm, but until then I find this makes minute adjustments to my Z-axis offset much easier.

This is the third variant of the Portable Air Conditioner/Heater prototypes. This version uses an actual radiator housed in front of a 120mm fan that provides either cool or warm air depending on the coolant used.

UPDATE: I added notches to the housing as I discovered the radiator had these.You may also need to sand down the sides inside the housing for a proper fit.

Type of radiator used in design: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CFDSB4C/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00CFDSB4C&linkCode=as2&tag=tmb03b-20&linkId=AZ3RBDCBSRFX2K47

6-32 machine screws are needed to fasten the fan, housing, radiator and front cover guard together.

Ice water is needed (or similar) for cooling and hot water (or similar) is needed for heating.

comments.text:
i am curios
does this work? i mean , is it making it a little bit cooler ?
comments.author: brooti1988

comments.text: An air conditioner works by removing heat from one area and discarding it in another. You'll get cold air blowing into your face for a bit until the ice melts. Unless this is absorbing the heat into the liquid and transporting it into another area (outside) where it is discarded in a condensor it won't cool your immediate area down.

The theory works. Depending on the method and complexity of the source and desired level of control this can work at many power levels, both DC and/or AC, as well as basic (hot water or ice water) or on a higher level (TEC components, and two of these used to cool a box or a PC). I have designed a similar type apparatus which was used for my senior project, the design included TEC components, and was more efficient than theory should allow for, as well as having the ability to work from 5VDC, 12VDC, or 120VAC.

description.text: Once you get a bunch of collar stays it can become quite a chore keeping them matched up.  This customizer lets you create a holder for them.  Simply indicate how large you want the holder to be and the customizer will distribute the appropriate number of slots in the box.

Use the customizer to design the box.  I printed my box using an infill of 15% since strength really isn't an issue.  The slots are wide to fit my full range of collar stay widths.  You should be able to get two collar stays into each slot.  If they are thin you may be able to get four.  
I got the idea from Ginobi_wan's box, but I wanted one that would fit perfectly in a tray I have and my printer handles this simpler version better.

description.text: At last! Here's the long-promised X-Carriage for my dual extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34821. This is a slightly modified version of Greg's X Carriage for the Prusa. author: GodoRo

description.text:
An update of my Zigzag desk tidy, this collection now includes 5 different waveforms as desktop trays.

All are simple to print, and include minimal supported versions where required. You'll want to print about 180mm x 180mm for pens, or smaller for rings, batteries, screws or paper clips!

The 5 waveforms are:

  • Sawtooth
  • Sine
  • Square
  • Triangle (previously zigzag)
  • Scallop

Feedback appreciated, and ideas for a second collection welcome!

Print the trays standing vertically, with minimal infill.

Layer height depends on quality required, and speed of print (at 0.15mm it can take a while)

There are versions of the Square and Sawtooth trays with added minimal supports, which are easy to snap off.

Remember to make sure you have random layer start points turned on to counter seams or scars.

author: prtsrs

description.text: Print without support

This is an adapter to use hein0170's backseat cinema iPad mount on a car with a less exposed headrest bar.  It is done in openscad so modification to other headrests should be relatively straightforward.  I was inspired by RyGuy's headrest mount system giving this design a simpler (although less sturdy) mounting mechanism than hein0170's.  
Be sure to read the instructions before printing.

You will need to print out the iPad holder portion from hein0170's backseat cinema and assemble it as he indicates. You will need two rods to span the distance between the headrests poles. Since they were easily available at our hardware store, I made the mount file to fit 3/8 in aluminum rod. You'll have to drill the holes out slightly if you go with hein0170's 10 mm rods. The only other hardware needed is for hein0170's iPad mount... 5 pcs M4 30mm (or preferred 25mm) bolts
5 pcs M4 nuts
one rubber band (optional) Adjust the "hole" openscad file if you need a different diameter head rest hole or a different depth to the iPad mount. This holder is going to take a lot of abuse so print it out with as much fill as you can, 80-100% would be best. You can generally fit several parts on the same plate. You won't need support, Once printed, you'll probably find you need to hammer the rods into the holes on the mount. It is suppose to be a tight fit. Be sure to put on the iPad holder before you put on the second end piece since it is difficult to get the rods out of the end mounts. You can add a rubber band to hein01790's design to make the top clamp spring loaded (see the 3rd picture). This is particularly handy in this situation (where the headrest is in the way) since it is a pain to tighten/loosen the screw every time you want to secure the iPad. To install it in your car, hook the hole pieces around your headrest holes and then slide the hooked ends into the mount pieces to secure the iPad mount. It should all be a tight fit. My print has plenty of friction to hold it all together. You could always glue the parts or add a screw if you wanted a more sturdy fit. The mount is less sturdy than hein0170's, but it is my only choice with my current headrests. So far I've used mine for almost 9 months with no obvious wear and tear (short of replacing the rubber band). Update: The optional rods file can be used to print 160mm long rods instead of buying the aluminum rod, if this size will work for you. It was reported by ConstantineC that ABS is plenty strong when printed with 100% infill. I've not used these ABS rods so let me know if they need any adjustment.

Printer: Makerfarm Prusa i3v.
Hotend: e3d-v6

comments.author: Eckerput

title: NefroBox: Small box for storing/holding screws or small things

description.text: I have had a lot of boxes to keep screws or small things together when I am working on a Project. None of them are helpful to pick up things with your fingers. This design allows me to use easily my fingers to take the screws. Being spheroidal the small objects are grouped and don't get trapped in the corners. I designed it with a separator in case I want to use it. Also is included a top (optional) for transport. The name NefroBox comes from its resemblance to a pair of kidneys. So if you have a spare pair of small kidneys you can also hold them here... Up and down parts have a ledge to help opening the box. Tolerances have been taken into account, so you don't have to file it too much to a perfect fit (so be careful when scaling). Freecad sources included. Maybe an improvement could be done adding a magnet at the bottom of the box... Or maybe printing the top with a translucent or flexible material... Or even adding a thread/lock... Or even adding it a side hole to support a screwdriver tip... Or add some led/button battery...
No special instructions required. Fill about a 15%, mínimum 4 shells. I recomend printing it in a very visible color like bright yellow or orange o even green to be seen easily between other stuff.

author: zolika79

description.text:
If you want to make your own professionnal blowgun, don't look anywhere else !

You just need a copper pipe (12mm ID and 14mm OD in this example), about 150cm long.

Then you can print the EMBOUCHURE file to blow inside. It fits right standard mouths.

The POIGNEE file is for a adjustable handle to help aiming with the blowgun.

The SORTIE_CANON file is for the other side of the blowgun, giving it a military look and prevent dust and durt going inside the copper pipe.

Also, you'll find a simple quiver, named CARQUOIS.

For the darts, I recommend you to make Fukiya style darts (just take a look on google). These darts are very unexpensive and very accurate if well made.

I've made a file name RONDELLE_CENTRAGE which allows to adjust the gravity center of the darts by gluying it inside the dart.

I recommend you to print those files with 50% infill to have stronger parts.

For the RONDELLE_CENTRAGE, 20% infill is fine to adjust the gravity center for 20cm long darts.

author: Bigman222

description.text:
When I got in charge of the Robo3d Printer I printed this for, we were having a clogging problem. After reading this guide we decided that the printer extruder needed more ventilation.
In order to be able to attach a bigger fan, I designed this piece from the shape and dimensions of the printer cart.
The piece is sideways to increase the conctact area with the bed.
It has a significant drawback: because of the Robo3d case, the printing volume is reduced with this duct, both in the x and z axis.

Just print it, with regular infill (20% worked for me), and then attach it to the head with a M4 40 mm screw.
It accepts M3 screws to fix the fan.
To be able to print without hitting the Robo3d case, the screw operating the x axis limit switch must be replaced with a 5 mm longer one, and the x dimension of the printing area must be reduced by 10 mm. Also, the z dimension of the printing volume must be reduced to 175 mm.

I modified a standard ZMR250 frame by removing the alu spacers and the top plate and replacing them with a 3D printed spacer holding all my electronics.

Build log here:
http://imgur.com/a/Oegau

Reddit thread here:
https://www.reddit.com/r/Multicopter/comments/3dy145/slim_zmr250_custom_clean_build/

Upon request, I have uploaded STLs of a few variations of the spacer. I hope somebody can make good use of them, or get an idea for his / her own builds.

Original versions
Spacer_V1.0_all_cuts_original - The original as I used in my build
Spacer_V1.0_buzzer_cut - The original with only the buzzer cut-out.
Spacer_V1.0_no_cuts - The original with no cuts at all

Alternative versions
Spacer_V1.1_all_cuts - This version is slightly thicker, has all the cut-outs my original has and has 5 mm bolt holes in stead of the original 3 mm. This allows for using standard 15mm alu M3 threaded spacers to be inserted into the bolt holes - provider better strength and off-loading the pressure on the plastic.

Used electronics

  • Naze32 Full Rev. 5
  • HC-05 BLuetooth module from here: (many shops carry these)
    http://www.hobbyelectronica.nl/product/hc-05-bluetooth-masterslave-module/
  • Spektrum 9654 satellite reciever
    https://www.spektrumrc.com/Products/Default.aspx?ProdID=SPM9645

Instructions on how to use a satellite receiver with the naze board are here:
http://www.netraam.eu/nazewiki/pmwiki.php?n=Howto.HookupASpektrumSatellite

Printer settings
If you're going for the original version without the aluminium inserted stand-offs, I suggest you use a fairly high shell thickness and fill rate. The only thing transferring the power from the motors to the body is the pressure from the spacer plate.

I used 3mm shell thickness with a 30% fill rate on my build.

V1.1 provides room for inserted spacers that can take the grunt of the force - offloading the plastic spacer. You can go for a reduced shell thickness and fill rate in that case.

Parts
The buzzer is a standard KK board buzzer from hobbyking, you can get it here:

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__47014__Piezo_Buzzer_for_KK2_KK2_1_Naze32_Flight_Control_Boards_1pc_.html

The switch I used is a Q15 toggle slide switch, any local electronics shop will have something like this in stock.

Well no matter how much I tensioned these things they eventually fall off.
This is usually the case because the shower curtain is left to one side or another making that side heavier. Or if you use heavier curtain rings type thing.
This is here to take up the weight a little. So after you tension the crap out of the rod use some of that picture frame 3M stickers and stick one of these at each end flush with the rod.

First attempt at modelling the Juggernog vending machine from Call of Duty. I've made the main body so that you can glue the Sign and coin slot onto it. This is, both, so you can paint the prints that way you want as well as the case of the 3D print not working properly so you don't have to print the whole model and waste material if something does go wrong with the print.

I'd love to see this model printed and customized by awesome people (That being everyone)

title: Affordable Rock Tumbler

description.text:
This is my affordable rock tumbler, designed to tumble 3D printed parts, printed in ColorFabbs metal filled filaments (BronzeFill, BrassFill, CopperFill).

It is also possible to add a 'golden' shine to regular PLA when the parts are tumbled with brass screws.

It should be possible to build this tumbler for less than € 40.- which makes it much more affordable than 'professional' tumblers that can do nothing better than this one ;-)

Please find the full instructions including the BOM here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Affordable-Rock-Tumbler
